ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: Approximately 5-7h the weeks I had to write a concept sheet for. Much more time for writing the 8,000 word essay.
several hours reading and writing reflections (on certain assigned weeks), and many more hours completing the substantial final paper
0-4 most weeks, much more for the final paper.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: This was an OUTSTANDING course. The best one I've taken at Yale so far. The level was perfect, we learnt a lot from leaders in their fields. We had access to people I would have never thought I would - and had lunch with them. I was looking forward to this course every week, I wish I could take it again.The only "drawback" is the 8,000 word essay students have to write, which is a little bit on the long side. I wish that requirement could have been for a slightly smaller essay. Overall though, the course was so good, I'd write a 20,000 word essay if I had to!THE BEST COURSE!!!!!!!!!!!! Congratulations to Drs Pogge and Ruger and a big THANK YOU to them for making this happen.
really enjoyed the guest speakers, excellent line up.
Strengths: brilliant speakers, novel topics.
Excellent group of lecturers
strength: various perspectives to approach health issues and many distinguished lecturers.Weakness: More helpful feedback for class preparation but a smaller project for the final.

This is one of the most unique classes I've taken thus far here. The variety and diversity of speakers we had was amazing and awe-inspiring. Dr. Pogge and Dr. Ruger are both amazing as well--this class truly was a treat.

This was a great course. It is absolutely amazing to get a chance to hear so many different points of view. My one recommendation is would be to offer some guidance on the final paper. Perhaps a required meeting with the professor or an outline. Of course people could probably do these things on their own and there is no need to baby graduate and professional students but some minimal requirement could have been helpful.
The course was amazing and invited very good dialogue on topics relevant to the class. One of the best classes I have taken thus far.

Strengths: Exposure to really high caliber lecturers. Also, the course allows you to do the majority of the work (concept papers, final paper) on topics of your choosing.Weaknesses: Inconsistent in discussion format; also unclear what the aims of some of the lectures were.

Strengths: Interesting topics. Lunch is a good idea. Best lectures: Emmanuel, Benn, (Ted) RugerAreas for improvement: Seems a bit HIV centric.Nix Ruger's lecture. Associations are meaningless without exploring how they may be or if they are causative factors. Not allowing questions during that lecture really rubbed me the wrong way, since a lively discussion is more important than another smattering of associations that hold no meaning. Also, forbidding question is at odds to the mission of learning. OR cut the content in half and allow discussion... the connections are important, but they need to be backed by discussion.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Jennifer Prah Ruger  In this course we didn't have a lot of teaching directly from the instructors but I know they spent a lot of time organizing the course and in that, they both did a great job. Dr Ruger participated by asking pertinent questions in the class room and during the lunches. I would highly recommend any course that she's involved with.
Instructor: Jennifer Prah Ruger  Good.
Instructor: Jennifer Prah Ruger  Very good at facilitating the dialogue between the guest speaker and the students
Instructor: Jennifer Prah Ruger  Finebut, more interaction with students is expected.
Instructor: Jennifer Prah Ruger  She was excellent and a very knowledgable woman. I enjoyed her genuine interest in class discussion and interaction with the guest speakers.
Instructor: Jennifer Prah Ruger  Very nice, very intelligent, but not much interaction/engagement with students. Could be improved by commenting on concept papers.

Instructor: Thomas Pogge  In this course we didn't have a lot of teaching directly from the instructors but I know they spent a lot of time organizing the course and in that, they both did a great job. Dr Pogge participated by asking pertinent questions in the class room and during the lunches. I would highly recommend any course that he's involved with.
Instructor: Thomas Pogge  Bright.
Instructor: Thomas Pogge  Likewise, he always had great questions and comments to keep the discussion moving in interesting directions
Instructor: Thomas Pogge  Fine, more interaction with students is expected.

Instructor: Thomas Pogge  He is an amazing professor and an asset to this class - he defines constructive criticism in his reviews, allowing for an excellent understanding of positive and negative aspects of the papers. He also engaged in class discussion with genuine interest and was a very understanding and caring individual.

Instructor: Thomas Pogge  Very helpful and responsive. Always answered my questions/got back to me, and gave me helpful comments on my concept papers.Both instructors' teaching could be improved by giving some more guidance on who the speakers are and what we should try to get out of their lecture.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This course gives you access to the leaders of the Global Health ethics field. It is extremely interesting and covers a lot of different aspects of global health. I enjoyed thoroughly and would HIGHLY recommend it to other students.
it would be nice to receive additional comments and feedbacks on assignments so students can get a better idea of their strengths and weaknesses on topics discussed
Perfect.
Excellent course to do diverse readings in global health and gain exposure to new ideas and potential areas of interest

As a course focusing on ethics, economics and politics, this course is quite different from the usual science courses we have within YSPH. Thus one may feel lost when doing the reading or listen to the lecture. But overall, I find the topics are quite interesting and even if you don't choose this course, I think you should try a similar one to know something about social science issues on global health. Workload is not so much except for the final, 8000 words paper!!
Fantastic course that gives you a deep understanding of a number of important global health problems and what kinds of work some remarkable people are doing to change them.

This class was a seminar style class with a different speaker each week who gave a perspective on a global health topic.I would absolutely recommend this class to anyone interested in global heath issues, international development, bioethics, and political science.
An excellent course that anyone interested in health and ethics should take.

This is a great course if you are not a law student, but still interested in these topics. Not every lecture will suit everyone, but there are lots of different important topics. It's a great way to take advantage of Yale's ability to attract interesting and important speakers.

It's a decent class and is similar to the Global Health Seminar. Youhave guest lecturers each week and there are assigned readings that usually- but not always- are related to what the lecturer is going to talk about. However, it is a lot of work. Three 4-8 page essays and a 32-40 pager. Don't take this class if you aren't a writer.
